comment.author: 84387357@N00
comment._content:
I was at the 1964 World's Fair: The most amazing part about these
"Expo" and World's Fair structures, is that they were so enormous, extensive and detailed in scope because they had to be... It was all a showcase of either national and/or international competition and pride. Yet nearly all you would have see there would have been ephemeral by design, set to have been mostly torn down after the big showcase was all over. That's part of what made it fascinating to visit these events: Just having known that fact. I would guess that the Columbian Exposition had more structures/buildings meant to remain as permanent structures than any other event of these type - at least here in America. Can anyone verify my guess above or refute it? TIA - Tony p.s. These are all fantastic contributions to the public's eye.
